titlepage.titleproper: Inventory for the Alexander A. Slaughter Papers, 1878-1966 and undated
titlepage.author: Abel Ramirez

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Alexander A. Slaughter Papers, 1878-1966 and undated
did.abstract: Personal and business papers of Alexander Averill Slaughter, the third son of Colonel C. C. Slaughter.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library, Texas Tech University

bioghist.head: Biographical Sketch
bioghist.p: Alexander Averill Slaughter was a rancher and entrepreneur. Born in 1881, he was the third son of Colonel C. C. Slaughter and Carrie Averill, C. C.'s second wife. He served in an official capacity in the family-owned-and-operated C. C. Slaughter Cattle Company. Upon his death in 1931, his widow, Dorothy L. Slaughter assumed direction of the estate and participated in the development of the petroleum industry in West Texas.

Born in 1837 in Sabine County, Texas, Christopher Columbus (C. C.) established frontier ranch in Palo Pinto County, Texas, in 1857 with his father, George Webb Slaughter, and his brothers. During the civil war, C. C. served in the frontier militia and in the Texas Rangers. Afterwards, he drove cattle over Chisholm Trail and later moved operations to West Texas where, by 1905, he owned 40,000 cattle and controlled over one million acres. Before his death in 1919, he had founded the American National Bank of Dallas (1884), and cofounded the Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association (1877), the Texas Baptist Education Commission (1897) and the Baylor Hospital of Dallas, Texas (1904).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, financial material, legal records, daily journals and cash books, literary productions, some printed material and photographs. A large portion of the materials deals with the minute details relevant to the daily operation of a ranching enterprise in West Texas and eastern New Mexico, and later (post-1937), the development of the petroleum industry in West Texas. The operations of the ranch under the supervision of Christopher Columbus (C. C.) and his son, Alexander Averill, are the focus of the papers within this collection.

arrangement.p: The papers are organized in the following series.

list.item: Box 1-6: C. C. Slaughter Cattle Company, 1886-1949 and undated
Box 6-7: C. C. Slaughter Company, 1912-1927 and undated
Box 7-9: Slaughter Building, 1898-1963 and undated
Box 9-10: Carrie A. Slaughter Estate, 1892-1945
Box 10-12: C. C. Slaughter, Jr., 1920-1928
Box 12: Carrie A. Slaughter Dean, 1927-1942
Box 12-14: Alexander A. Slaughter, 1891-1958 and undated
Box 14-25: Dorothy L. Slaughter, 1878-1966 and undated
Box 25: W. B. Handley, 1948-1963
Box 25: Slaughter Family, 1908-1942 and undated
Box 26 and 26 Ledgers: Financial Materials, 1897-1964

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: The subject headings used by the Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library are derived from the Library of Congress and/or locally developed.

controlaccess.head: Subjects (Organizations)
controlaccess.corpname: C. C. Slaughter Cattle Company--Records and correspondence

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Alexander A. Slaughter Papers, 1878-1966 and undated, Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, Texas

bibliography.head: Additional Sources
bibliography.bibref: Murrah, David J. C. C. Slaughter, rancher, banker, Baptist. Austin: University of Texas Press, 1981.
Murrah, David J. A Cattle Kingdom on Texas' Last Frontier: C. C. Slaughter's Lazy S Ranch. Thesis (M.A.)--Texas Tech University, 1970.
